questions.text: The most commonly used Laser in laryngeal surgeries is
questions.solution:
Explanation:

CO2 Laser is the most commonly used laser in laryngeal surgeries, especially for procedures involving the vocal cords, as it provides:

  1. Precise cutting
  2. Minimal thermal damage
  3. Excellent control in microlaryngeal surgery

  • Used for excision of: Vocal nodules, polyps, cysts, granulomas, and juvenile papillomas
  • Precision: Spot size of 3 mm allows accurate cutting
  • Techniques:
    1. Lesions are delineated and dissected using microlaryngeal instruments
    2. Micro-flaps used in Reinke's oedema treatment
  • Other Indications:
    1. Leukoplakia, T1 vocal cord lesions
    2. Localised lesions in the supraepiglottis and infraepiglottis
    3. Transverse cordotomy and endoscopic arytenoidectomy for bilateral abductor paralysis

Explanation for other options:

Argon Laser (Option A): Visible laser used more in dermatology and retinal surgery, less common in the larynx.

Holmium Laser (Option C): Mainly used in urology (e.g., lithotripsy).

Nd YAG Laser (Option D): Penetrates deeply, used for tumour debulking, but not preferred for delicate laryngeal work due to the risk of deep tissue damage.

choices.text: Laryngomalacia
Congenital Subglottic Stenosis
Acquired Subglottic stenosis
Laryngealweb

questions.text: A 10-month-old infant was born premature and was intubated for 10 days. He was doing well for 6 months, but for the last 4 months, he developed progressively worsening inspiratory and expiratory (biphasic) stridor. On examination, there was audible biphasic stridor and muscle retractions. The most likely diagnosis is
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The history of intubation and Biphasic stridor makes acquired subglottic stenosis the most likely diagnosis.

Prolonged intubation -> endotracheal tube causes pressure necrosis -> mucosaloedema and ulceration -> heals by deposition of fibrous tissue in submucosa -> subglottic stenosis.

Acquired Subglottic/Laryngotracheal Stenosis (SGS/LTS) in children:

Overview

  • Most common cause: Prolonged intubation
  • Typical patients: Premature infants or those with birth defects
  • Goal of treatment: Prevent tracheostomy or achieve decannulation

Anatomy

  • The pediatric larynx lies high in the neck
  • Cricoid cartilage is the narrowest, most vulnerable to injury

Presentation

  • Symptoms: Stridor, failed extubation, tracheostomy dependence
  • Voice change: suggests supraglottic/glottic involvement
  • Comorbidities: GERD, aspiration, cardiac/pulmonary disease

Examination

  • Stridor type (inspiratory/expiratory/biphasic)
  • Flexible endoscopy; assess for:
    • SGS, glottic web, PGS, vocal cord paralysis

Diagnosis

  • MLB (Microlaryngobronchoscopy) = gold standard
  • Myer-Cotton classification for SGS severity
  • Imaging: X-ray, CT with contrast, Barium swallow, polysomnography

Treatment

  • Treat inflammation first: GERD (PPIs), eosinophilic oesophagitis (topical steroids)
  • Mild SGS (Grade I-II): Endoscopic balloon dilatation ± steroid injection/incision
  • Refractory cases: Open LTR or cricotracheal resection

Explanation for other options:

Laryngomalacia (Option A): This is the most common cause of stridor in infants, but it presents early (within a few weeks of birth) with inspiratory stridor only (not biphasic), which improves in the prone position and worsens with crying or feeding. The delayed onset after 6 months of age and biphasic stridor rule this out.

Congenital Subglottic Stenosis (Option B): This would typically cause persistent symptoms from birth or early infancy, not delayed or progressively worsening symptoms starting at 6 months. Also, there's no history of intubation needed for congenital stenosis.

Laryngeal Web (Option D): Usually congenital, and symptoms begin early in life with a high-pitched cry or stridor from birth. If it's acquired, it would need a history of trauma or surgery, not just intubation. Onset at 6 months after being symptom-free initially doesn't favour this.

choices.text: Injury to the Vagus nerve
Vocal nodules
Intubation Granuloma
Functional aphonia

questions.text: A 45-year-old female was operated on for emergency appendectomy under general anaesthesia. After surgery, she is complaining of hoarseness of voice. What can be the most probable aetiology?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

This patient was given general anaesthesia, which implies that she has been intubated. Therefore, intubation granuloma is the most probable cause of these complaints. It is an iatrogenic entity.

Intubation granuloma

  • Due toinjury to the vocal processes of the arytenoids, caused by rough intubation, the use of a large tube, or the prolonged presence of a tube between the cords.
  • The site of granuloma formation is at the junction of the anterior two-thirds and posterior one-third of the vocal cord.
  • Always Bilateral involvement
  • Mucosal ulceration is followed by granuloma formation over the exposed cartilage.
  • Present with hoarseness and, if large, dyspnoea as well.
  • The treatment is microlaryngeal surgery.
  • The focal length of the microscope used for MLS of the larynx is 400 mm.

Explanation for other options:

Injury to the Vagus nerve (Option A): While the vagus nerve innervates the larynx (via the recurrent and superior laryngeal nerves), injury to the main vagus during appendectomy is extremely unlikely. Such an injury would cause multiple deficits, not just hoarseness.

Vocal nodules (Option B): These are bilateral lesions from chronic vocal abuse (e.g., singers, teachers) and develop gradually over time, not acutely after surgery. Sudden hoarseness post-intubation does not support this diagnosis.

Functional aphonia (Option D): This is a psychogenic condition with normal vocal cord movement on laryngoscopy and absence of organic pathology. It typically occurs in stress-related scenarios, not as a direct result of surgery or intubation.

choices.text: Intralesional Cidofovir helps reduce the recurrence rate
Indole-3-carbinol, derived from cruciferous vegetables, has shown some benefit
Microlaryngeal surgery with CO2 laser is the primary modality of treatment
Only involve the supraglottis and the Glottis

questions.text: Which of the following is not applicable statement of Recurrent respiratory papillomatosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

While the supraglottis and glottis are the most commonly involved sites, recurrent respiratory papillomatosis can also extend to the subglottis, trachea, bronchi, and, in rare cases, even the lung parenchyma.

Explanation for other options:

Intralesional Cidofovir (Option A):

Cidofovir is an antiviral agent used off-label in Recurrent Respiratory Papillomatosis (RRP). It is injected directly into the lesions to reduce the recurrence rate by inhibiting viral replication.

Indole-3-carbinol (Option B):

This is a compound derived from cruciferous vegetables like broccoli and cabbage. It has shown some benefit in RRP by modulating estrogen metabolism, which may affect papilloma growth.

Microlaryngeal surgery with CO2 laser (Option C):

This is the primary modality of treatment in RRP. It allows for precise removal of papillomas with minimal damage to surrounding tissues. Surgery is often repeated as papillomas recur.

choices.text: Oesophagal voice has a high-quality voice and a very good success rate
The electrolarynx is a handheld device
The Blom-Singer prosthesis is surgically fitted between the trachea and the oesophagus
Patient has a permanent tracheotomy after total laryngectomy

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about the vocal rehabilitation of a laryngectomised patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Oesophageal voice has a poor quality and has a 50 % success rate only, as it is a difficult technique to learn.

  • Patient is taught to swallow air and hold it in the upper oesophagus and then slowly eject it from the oesophagus into the pharynx.
  • The patient can speak six to ten words before reswallowing air.

Explanation for other options:

The electrolarynx is a handheld device (Option B): This is a battery-operated device held against the neck or cheek. It generates vibrations that are transformed into speech sounds. While it produces a robotic voice, it is easy to use and commonly used initially after surgery.

The Blom-Singer prosthesis is surgically fitted between the trachea and the oesophagus (Option C): This is a tracheoesophageal voice prosthesis that allows pulmonary air to pass into the oesophagus to produce speech. It is placed through a fistula created between the trachea and oesophagus during or after laryngectomy.

Patient has a permanent tracheotomy after total laryngectomy(Option D): In total laryngectomy, the larynx is removed, and the airway is separated from the mouth and nose. The trachea is permanently diverted to a tracheostoma in the neck for breathing.

CO2 laser is the most frequently used laser in ENT surgery
Silicon Endotracheal tube wrapped with metallic foil should be used for laser-assisted laryngeal surgeries
A CO2 laser can pass through the flexible endoscopes

questions.text: All of the following are true about lasers in ENT except
questions.solution:
Explanation:

CO2 lasers cannot be transmitted via fibre optics or flexible endoscopes because:

  • Glass fibres strongly absorb their 10,600 nm infrared wavelength
  • CO2 lasers typically require articulated arms or micromanipulators for delivery in ENT procedures

Explanation for other Options:

Argon and KTP lasers are visible lasers, whereas CO2 lasers and Nd: YAG lasers are invisible (Option A):

  • Argon and KTP lasers emit light in the visible spectrum (blue-green).
  • CO2 and Nd: YAG lasers emit infrared light, which is invisible to the human eye.

CO2 laser is the most frequently used laser in ENT surgery(Option B):

  • CO2 laser is widely used due to:
    • High precision
    • Minimal thermal damage
    • Excellent control in microlaryngeal and nasal surgeries

Silicon endotracheal tube wrapped with metallic foil should be used for laser-assisted laryngeal surgeries (Option C):

  • Standard practice to prevent airway fires during laser procedures
  • Laser-resistant tubes (metal-wrapped or laser-safe) are essential in airway surgeries

choices.text: Early vocal cord nodules are managed with speech therapy
Pachydermia laryngis is a premalignant condition
Reinke's oedema is best managed with decortication of the vocal cords
CO2 laser is very useful in the management of juvenile papilloma of the larynx

questions.text: Which of the following statements is not true about vocal cord lesions?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Pachydermia laryngis is not a premalignant condition.

  • It is a heaping up of epithelium in the interarytenoid region and the posterior thirds of the vocal cord due to vocal abuse and laryngopharyngeal reflux.
  • It is bilateral and symmetrical.
  • Biopsy is used to differentiate between carcinoma and tuberculosis.

Explanation for other options:

Early vocal cord nodules are managed with speech therapy (Option A):

  • Vocal cord nodules are benign, bilateral, symmetric lesions seen in people with voice abuse (e.g., teachers, singers).
  • Initial treatment: Conservative management with speech therapy and voice rest.

Reinke's oedema is best managed with decortication of the vocal cords (Option C):

  • Reinke's oedema involves fluid accumulation in the superficial lamina propria (Reinke's space) of the vocal cords.
  • Treatment: Microlaryngoscopic surgical decortication, especially if voice therapy fails or the lesion is large.

CO2 laser is very useful in the management of juvenile papilloma of the larynx (Option D):

  • Juvenile-onset recurrent respiratory papillomatosis is treated with CO2 laser excision to remove papillomas.
  • Laser offers precision and minimal bleeding.

choices.text: Voice rest
Microlaryngoscopic removal
Cryotherapy
Speech therapy

questions.text: The Treatment of choice for vocal polyps is :
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Microlaryngoscopic removal is the treatment of choice for vocal polyps.

Vocal Polyps:

Aetiology & Site: Same as vocal nodules - vocal abuse, possibly LPR; located at the junction of the anterior 1/3 and posterior 2/3 of the vocal cords.

Key Difference: Polyps are usually unilateral compared to vocal nodules, which are bilateral.

Types:

Symptoms: Dysphonia (hoarseness); diplophonia in large polyps.

Treatment:

  • Micro Laryngeal Surgery (MLS) under a microscope
  • Followed by speech therapy to prevent recurrence

Microscope Focal Lengths:

  • Ear: 200-250 mm
  • Nose: 300 mm
  • Larynx: 400 mm

Explanation for other options:

Voice rest (Option A): This is useful in early or minor lesions and to reduce strain, but not a definitive treatment for established vocal polyps. Most polyps are fibrous and require surgical removal.

Cryotherapy (Option C): Cryotherapy is not standard for vocal polyps. It is more often used in laryngeal papillomas or malignancies, where tissue destruction is required. Vocal polyps are best managed with excision.

Speech therapy (Option D): Helpful as an adjunct to surgery for rehabilitating voice function and preventing recurrence. However, it is not curative for existing polyps.

Key Takeaway:

Vocal polyp is caused by sudden shouting, resulting in haemorrhage in the vocal cord and subsequent submucosal oedema. Treatment is surgical excision under an operating microscope, followed by speech therapy.
